raw_text:
Johnny Cash manager Holiff dies
 
 The former manager of Johnny Cash, Saul Israel Holiff, has died at the age of 79, his family said.
 
 Mr Holiff, who was also a concert promoter, managed Cash's career between 1960 and 1973, quitting when he thought the singer's career had peaked. "I was guilty for underestimating him repeatedly," he once said. The Canadian music manager, who also managed Tommy Hunter and the Statler Brothers, had been in declining health, according to his family. An entrepreneur from an early age, Mr Holiff served as a rear air gunner in the Royal Canadian Air Force during World War II, afterwards setting up a drive-in restaurant. He briefly dabbled in acting, before setting up offices in Nashville and Los Angeles for his concert and artist promotion business. In 1970, RPM weekly magazine presented Holiff with a special award as the Canadian music industry's man of the year. Mr Holiff retired when he was in his late 40s, returning to education as a mature student at the University of Victoria, where he graduated with a degree in history. He passed away on 17 March. According to his wishes, there will be no funeral service.
llama3.2:1b: Johnny Cash's former manager Saul Israel Holiff has died at 79 after a career managing his career from 1960-1973 and retiring due to declining health.
llama3.2:3b: Saul Israel Holiff, Johnny Cash's manager from 1960-1973, has died at age 79, due to declining health.
gemma2:2b: Saul Israel Holiff, former manager of Johnny Cash and concert promoter, died at age 79. He managed Cash's career from 1960-1973 before retiring. A Canadian entrepreneur with a history in the Royal Canadian Air Force and acting, he was awarded "Man of the Year" for the music industry in 1970.  He passed away on March 17th without a funeral service.

He retired at age 45 and returned to education, earning a history degree from the University of Victoria. No funeral service will be held according to his wishes.

Saul Israel Holiff, former manager of Johnny Cash, passed away at 79 following managing Cash between 1960 and 1973. His family requested no funeral service.Holiff was a concert promoter with a career spanning several decades, contributing to the music industry and inspiring others through his work. In 1970, he received an award from RPM magazine for being a man of the year in the Canadian music industry. After retirement, he resumed education at the University of Victoria, where he earned his degree in history.
tinyllama:1.1b: Johnny Cash's former manager Saul Israel Holiff has died at age 79, his family said. Mr Holiff managed Cash's career between 1960 and 1973, quitting when he thought Cash's career had peaked. The Canadian music manager, who also worked for Tommy Hunter and the Statler Brothers, was known for underestimating Cash repeatedly, according to his family. During his early years as a driver during World War II, Mr Holiff served as an rear air gunner in the Royal Canadian Air Force. He later opened drive-in restaurants and acting studios before setting up offices in Nashville and Los Angeles for his concert and artist promotion business. In 1970, RPM weekly magazine presented Holiff with a special award as the Canadian music industry's man of the year. Mr Holiff retired when he was in his late 40s, returning to education as a matriculation student at the University of Victoria where he graduated with a degree in history. He passed away on March 17, and no funeral service has been announced yet.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Johnny Cash's former manager Saul Israel Holiff has died at the age of 79. Mr. Holiff, who was an experienced concert promoter in his own right, took on the challenge of guiding Johnny Cash's career when he felt that it had reached its zenith. Despite his health declining, Holiff decided to retire from active management at the age of 40, returning to education and graduating with a degree in history from the University of Victoria.

Holiff, a World War II veteran, had a diverse career, including running a drive-in restaurant and briefly acting before establishing a music promotion business in Nashville and Los Angeles. He was named Canadian music industry's man of the year by RPM magazine in 1970. Retiring in his late 40s, he later earned a history degree from the University of Victoria. In 1970, RPM weekly magazine honored him as Canada's music industry figure of the year. Upon retiring at around age 45 to pursue higher education, he wished for no funeral service.
